article:
{{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=Wall Street |alternate_name= |image=Wall
Street Sign NYC.jpg |maint= |map= |length_mi= 0.7 |length_round= |length_ref=
|length_notes= |established= |decommissioned= |direction_a=West
|terminus_a=Broadway |junction= |direction_b=East |terminus_b=South Street
|counties=New York |cities= |system= }} on Wall Street, the world's largest
stock exchange per total market capitalization of its listed
companies. ]]




'Wall Street' is the financial district of New York
City, [http://www.nyc.gov/html/dcp/pdf/lucds/mn1profile.pdf Profile of
Manhattan Community Board 1], retrieved July 17, 2007. named after and
centered on the eight-block-long, long street running from Broadway to South
Street on the East River in Lower Manhattan. Over time, the term has become a
metonym for the financial markets of the United States as a whole, the American
financial sector (even if financial firms are not physically located there), or
signifying New York-based financial interests. [http://mw1.merriam-
webster.com/dictionary/Wall%20Street Merriam-Webster Online], retrieved July 17,
2007. It is the home of the New York Stock Exchange, the world's largest
stock exchange by market capitalization of its listed companies. [http://www.world-
exchanges.org World-exchanges.org] Several other major exchanges have or
had headquarters in the Wall Street area, including NASDAQ, the New York
Mercantile Exchange, the New York Board of Trade, and the former American Stock
Exchange. Anchored by Wall Street, New York City is one of the world's principal
financial centers.
